thread.title: Father who suffocated two-year-old child jailed
thread.title_full: Father who suffocated two-year-old child jailed

author: Deena Coster
title: Father who suffocated two-year-old child jailed

persons.name: andy jackson/fairfax nz  philip murray kinraid

text:
Dad jailed for suffocating his toddler daughter Father who suffocated two-year-old child jailed DEENA COSTER Last updated 12:56, February 22 2017 Andy Jackson/Fairfax NZ 
Philip Murray Kinraid was jailed for four years and three months for the manslaughter of his two-year-old daughter. 
A father who caused the death of his youngest child has been jailed for four years and three months. 
On Wednesday, Philip Murray Kinraid appeared in the High Court at New Plymouth to be sentenced for the manslaughter of his daughter Esme Claire Kinraid in June 2015. 
The maximum penalty for manslaughter is life imprisonment. Andy Jackson/Fairfax NZ 
Philip Murray Kinraid at his sentencing for the manslaughter of his two-year-old daughter on Wednesday. 
Justice Rebecca Ellis said between 7 and 7.30pm on June 26, Kinraid was at his Hawera home with his partner and two children. 
READ MORE: * Father speaks out about baby's death: 'I feel guilty about the what ifs' 
When he put the children to bed, Esme became upset and began to cry. Several attempts were made to settle her. 
After moving her to the spare room, Kinraid held her down in the bed with enough force to stop her from getting up. Kinraid said Esme was squirming around and screaming during this time, Ellis said. 
He continued to restrain her, holding her face down into the pillow until she let out a "shuddering breath", Ellis said 
At this point Kinraid said she appeared to be breathing normally so he adjusted her head to the side and left the room. 
Later that night, Kinraid was called into work. After getting home, his partner asked him to check on Esme before they went to bed. 
When he went into the room about 11pm, he noticed she was not breathing or moving and one side of her face was discoloured. "You said to the 111 operator 'I think I might have killed my daughter'," Ellis said. 
Attempts were made to save Esme's life but they were unsuccessful. 
Esme was Philip Kinraid's youngest child. He is now estranged from his former partner and son. A permanent suppression order protection their identities was made by Justice Ellis on Wednesday. 
Prior to the sentencing, defence counsel Jo Woodcock argued for permanent suppression orders to be granted in relation to two aspects of the case but this was opposed by the Crown, Fairfax and TVNZ. 
A ruling was made by Justice Ellis to lift the suppression regarding one of the elements but an immediate appeal was filed by Woodcock. 
As a result, an interim order for the suppression order to remain in place was granted until an appeal hearing can be held. 
A first strike warning against Kinraid was issued when he pleaded guilty in November 2016.
